results.title: Showtime
results.creator_credit: Anne Bourke and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description:
A film of the Royal Melbourne Show as seen through the eyes of a family group. Grandfather, a retired farmer, takes his daughter and her two teenage children to the show. To people like breeders of livestock, farmers and agricultural equipment salesmen, the show is an important yearly event, but for the family there is something to interest each member. Cooking demonstrations, displays of horsemanship, and the extensive pavilions showing domestic pets as well as farm animals all have their appeal.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:14:00 animated graphics title ‘Showtime’, ‘produced by State Film Centre Victoria Westrex Sound’
00:00:30:00 a 1950s model crane truck
00:00:45:00 a 1950s model electricians van with lettering for ‘RHC Sound System’
00:00:57:00 scenes of preparing for the Show - cleaning, painting tyres and signs, brushing cattle
00:01:26:00 first look at animals on show in the main arena
00:02:16:00 draft horses
00:02:26:00 goats
00:02:35:00 and showing off the fleece on a large ram and holding a large rooster up to the camera
00:02:50:00 the Berkshire pigs at the Show
00:03:02:00 a ‘red rattler’ style Show Special train pulls into the platform and people disembark, including the narrator and his family who quickly start looking at exhibits at the Show
00:03:53:00 first showbag pavilion
00:04:05:00 signs for popular soft drink at the time. Tarax
00:04:30:00 the Guernsey cattle pavilion
00:05:06:00 bundles of wheat and Government information about wheat on display
00:05:29:00 baby hen chicks
00:05:55:00 large flock of sheep
00:06:05:00 Centenary Hall at the Melbourne Showgrounds followed by exhibitions of shearing sheep with hand shears and then with electric shears
00:06:35:00 a fashion parade at the Show followed by doll making and hand knits craft exhibition
00:07:27:00 looking at exhibitions of food preservation, tiered wedding cakes, and cooking class on laminations
00:07:45:00 whitegoods exhibition beginning with a well stocked drinks cabinet with built in fridge and semi-automatic washing machine in action
00:07:59:00 an exhibition set up as a butchers shop shows sausage making
00:08:15:00 the wood-chopping exhibition and competition at the Show followed by exhibition of different types of chainsaws
00:09:00:00 the diary pavilion
00:09:17:00 inspecting the brand new, shining Massey-Ferguson tractors tried out by very keen young man of the family
00:09:44:00 new motor cars on show including a promotion for the new Ford Zephyr
00:09:55:00 carnival rides including the ‘Noddy Car Ride’ (character featured in Enid Blyton books)
00:10:30:00 aerial view of the Showgrounds
00:10:46:00 sideshow tents
00:11:47:00 fairy floss tent
00:11:55:00 cut flowers pavilion
00:12:16:00 dog show
00:13:30:00 the Australian Mint exhibition followed by several show bag stalls
00:14:15:00 crowds at the main arena followed by horse jumping, harness racing and other competitions, including what might be sheaf sack tossing
00:15:09:00 the Grand Parade in the main arena at the Show which includes many of the exhibitors, winners and placegetters
00:17:07:00 fireworks and title ‘The End’

results.title: Port of Melbourne
results.creator_credit: Jennie Blackwood, Melbourne Harbor Trust Commissioners and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description: The Port of Melbourne and its behind-the-scenes organisation: the routing of a ship up river, the allocation of berths and tugs, harbour traffic control, cargo handling from ship to rail and road truck, future planning for the harbour, routine inspections and dredging and finally a first aid and rescue squad in action.

results.title: Matchmaker at work
results.brief_description: Outlines recent developments in the CRA group, including: - establishment of Hamersley’s second mine complex at Paraburdoo; the Bougainville Copper operation; Comalco’s integrated aluminium group, and integration of lead zinc interests into Australian Mining and Smelting.

results.title: Loop
results.brief_description: A documentary about Melbourne’s Underground Rail Loop, its effect on the entire metropolitan railway system, and on the future of public transport in Melbourne. Shows the route the loop tracks and tunnels will follow around the city, the sites for the three new underground stations to supplement the present two stations, how passengers will travel from suburban stations when the loop is operating, how the loop is being constructed, and the benefits for train travellers of having five city stations close to shops, theatres and offices. Photographed by Volk Mol, sound by Don Boardman, edited by Geoff Wright, narrated by Michael Pate. Produced for the Melbourne Underground Rail Loop Authority.

results.title: Late again
results.creator_credit: Brighton Grammar School (Vic.). Film Makers Club
results.brief_description: A good example of school film making. The boys are late to school again, the master waits with a cane. The attempt to overcome their problems causes the downfall of the master’s wife.
results.description: A good example of school film making. The boys are late to school again, the master waits with a cane. The attempt to overcome their problems causes the downfall of the master’s wife.

results.title: [Lasker and Lasker Surf Outfitters: bathing suits and caps: advertisement]
results.brief_description: Promotes Lasker and Lasker Surf Outfitters of 402 and 404 George St, Sydney, N.S.W. Women and men model bathing suits and caps on a beach. Shots include the models standing next to a surf boat, models with parasols, and a model putting on a beach coat. (Cinema advertisement, includes intertitles).

results.title: Hennessy's holiday
results.brief_description: The visit to Melbourne of Hennessy, a 180-pound St. Bernard dog. He sees the Botanical Gardens, the Sidney Myer Music Bowl, and the Shrine, and takes a run around the M.C.G. After intensive grooming he wins a prize at the Royal Melbourne Show, the takes a ride on the “Mightie Mouse” [sic], and he also enjoys a ride on Puffing Billy and a spin on the bay in a speedboat. A modelling appointment, having his portrait drawn by a cartoonist, and an appearance on ‘In Melbourne Tonight’ help make his visit a memorable one for all.

results.title: Grapes are growing
results.creator_credit: Peter Menzies, John Kingsford-Smith, Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation and Kingcroft Productions
results.brief_description: Traces the history of Australia’s wine industry. Shows the factors leading to high quality grapes; the process of wine making in which grapes are tested, weighed, transported, crushed, fermented, stored and bottled ready for use. Includes the traditional method of making ‘champagne’ and the importance of the Australian Wine Research Institute and Roseworthy College.

results.title: Gateway to a city [West Gate Bridge]
results.creator_credit: David Morgan, John Richardson and Kestrel Films (Australia)
results.brief_description: Melbourne’s West Gate Bridge is a gateway to the future - a future of unprecedented residential, commercial and industrial growth for Melbourne and its Western regions. This film of the opening ceremony gives a historical outlook to the development of the river, shipping and the effects on the growth of the city of Melbourne.

results.title: Don't be strained
results.creator_credit: Stan Murdoch, Reg Perier and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1963 film illustrates techniques for manual handling to avoid muscle strain. The film shows workers in various factories undertaking manual labour, and includes footage of an officer of the New South Wales Department of Public Health instructing workers on the correct methods of lifting to avoid injuries such as muscle strain, slipped discs and hernias. The film applies these methods of lifting to other scenarios, including a woman at a filing cabinet, a woman putting out the washing and a postman bending to a letterbox. The narrator refers to ‘the human machine’ throughout the film.

Produced by the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.
